incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Permian Equipment Rentals LLC
incidents.Incident Description:
On January 29, 2026, Permian Equipment employee was operating unit 222 and was involved in a traffic incident on the I-10 access road in San Antonio, Texas.

The driver reported that the company vehicle was struck from behind by a third-party vehicle. No visible damage was observed on the company vehicle at the scene. The third-party vehicle sustained reported damage to the hood, front bumper, and right fender.

At the time of the incident, no injuries were reported.

After the event, the third-party driver submitted a claim alleging that the company vehicle attempted to pass and made contact with their vehicle. A police report has since been identified and we are waiting to review.

incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.Incident Description: Poly crew members were in the processes of transferring poly pipe from one spool trailer onto another. When employee went to cut the sash cord holding the pipe, poly pipe went sideways between the rails and made contact with employee's face. Employee was taken to XstremeMD and was referred to be taken to Midland Memorial hospital. Please see attachments.

incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.Incident Description:
Incident Description
An employee was in the process of setting anchors on a multi-well pad. A valid One Call ticket was in hand, and the location had been properly flagged. Two anchors were installed without incident. While setting the third anchor, the employee struck a steel line approximately six inches below ground surface.

Upon contact, the line ruptured and released a large volume of air. No water or oil was observed. The employee immediately shut down operations and vacated the area. The incident was promptly reported to management and Permian personnel.

The employee was instructed to move his truck out of the area if it could be done safely. He was able to relocate the vehicle without issue. Permian personnel arrived on location and identified the damaged line as a compressed air line. They isolated and closed the line, eliminating the release.

Permian then contacted their line locate group to fully locate the line. Our truck will remain released from the area until the line has been completely located and the job is cleared to resume

incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.Incident Description:
The crew had 4-inch poly line already cut and was in the process of connecting the line to a hammer union and placing it on a table. Approximately 200 feet of poly line had been spooled out, with about 10 feet curved near the work area.

The employee was holding the 4-inch poly line by hand while positioning it into a clamp to be welded to the hammer union. During this process, the employee’s footing slipped, causing his hand to release the poly line. The line shifted and struck the employee in the face.

Employee was evaluated at XstremeMD, referred to Midland Memorial Hospital for precautionary imaging, and later returned to XstremeMD for follow-up and released full duty with no restrictions.

incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.Incident Description: First Aid - On January 27, 2026, 3rd party Martin Aragon (First Tier) was performing work in the area and attempting to position a tagline between two beams. At the time, ground conditions were muddy due to recent weather. While stepping into position, Mr. Aragon lost his footing on the slick surface and slipped. As he attempted to brace his fall, he landed on his arm and reported pain in the left elbow area, with visible bruising and swelling noted. Work was stopped and the individual was transported to Priority Urgent Care for evaluation. Mr. Aragon was later released and returned to full duty with no work restrictions. No BRHAS employees were involved in the incident.

incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.Incident Description:
The employee was traveling westbound on the I-20 service road and approached a blockade at the intersection of South County Road 1276. The driver attempted to make a right-hand turn onto South County Road 1276 to go around the blockade.

During the turn, the vehicle lost traction on the icy roadway and slid, striking a wooden post. No injuries were reported.
incidents.Rig / Well: Intersection of I 20 westbound service road and S County Rd 1276

incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.Incident Type: At-Fault Vehicle Accident, Equipment Damage/Property Damage
incidents.Incident Description: The driver was returning to the shop unit #E17544C with trailer #E33818 and traveling eastbound on Highway 128 approximately 3.3 miles from the Highway 115 intersection when the vehicle hit a patch of ice. The trailer began to sway, became detached from the truck, and overturned onto its side. No injuries were reported.
incidents.Rig / Well: Hwy 128 near the intersection of Hwy 128 and Hwy 115.

incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.Incident Description:
During casing operations on OXY HP 415 the crew had completed makeup of the landing joint and was preparing to remove the flush mounts.  The crew hooked up to the flush mount and lifted with the hoist when a Cameron Surface System torque key installed on the landing joint disengaged and struck a crew member on the right shoulder. No injury occurred and no medical treatment was required.

Equipment Involved:
Third party Cameron Surface
Systems Torque key installed as part of the landing joint configuration

Immediate Cause:
Disengagement of third-party Cameron Surface Systems torque key during hoist activity. 

Contributing Factors:
Use of Cameron Surface Systems torque key that was later reviewed by Cameron Surface Systems operations and determined to be unnecessary for Cameron landing joint operations and deemed overkill for the application. 

Corrective actions (completed):
- Cameron Surface systems remove torque keys from all Oxy drilling rig operations.
- Cameron technicians instructed to communicate with drillers to avoid applying rotational torque during CRT installation. 
- Cameron assigned account oversight to ensure torque keys are not used on Oxy locations moving forward.
- BRHAS crews reminded to verify equipment configuration prior to hoisting activities and to maintain clear lift-area awareness.

incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.Incident Description: NAFMVA - Butch's shop mechanic was driving Unit #2277 heading South Bound on N. Big Springs. At the intersection of N. Big Springs and Occidental Street, a 3rd party vehicle (Exact Valve Solutions) was pulling a utility trailer #1219 and was in the middle lane facing North bound and was trying to make a left-hand turn onto Occidental Street. 3rd party driver had the yellow-yield light on Stop light and our shop mechanic driver had the green light. At the intersection, 3rd party made the left turn when our truck unit was near the intersection, our driver made an attempt to avoid collision but still made contact with 3rd party utility trailer. No injuries were noted from 3rd party or our driver. Please see attachments.
incidents.Rig / Well: Intersection of N. Big Springs and Occidental Street

incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.Incident Description: IE was rolling pipe for 5 1/2 casing run, when the casing went onto the trough of the catwalk crooked. The IE then went onto the catwalk platform to attempt to push the casing into the trough. As he pushed the casing on, his right foot slipped onto the catwalk and the pipe rolled on top of his foot. He was taken to Xstreme MD for evaluation and released for full duty with no restrictions

incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.Incident Description: NAFMVA - Pit lining crew member was driving Unit #2337 and was heading West bound on 5100 block of 42nd street. Pit lining crew member was driving in the outside lane, when a 3rd party vehicle was driving East bound, got in the middle lane and made an attempt to make a left-hand turn and made contact with our truck unit. Please see attachments. No Injuries were noted.

incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.Incident Description: While making up 9 5/8 inch casing, tong operator was applying torque to the pipe in low gear.  At this point tong operator felt tension on the hoist line at this point the tongs came up approximately 9 feet, then came down about 6 feet.  Tong operator jumped back and noticed that the base plate and the tong heads were on the rig floor.

incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.Incident Description: IP pinched his thumb while using the 3.5” mud hose. First Aid. Post Alcohol and Drug Test conducted.

incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Permian Equipment Rentals LLC
incidents.Incident Description: Employee was traveling eastbound on Loop 250 when he struck a wooden barrier, resulting in damage to the company vehicle’s side mirrors and front windshield.

incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.Incident Description: The casing joint had been rotating for approximately two hours when the company man requested the joint be backed out. The crew hauler set the slips, and tongs were placed on the joint to back it out. Torque on the CRT had not been released prior to the tongs being applied. When the tongs were engaged, the stored torque caused the tongs to spin, and the bails caught on the tong hoist, lifting the tongs approximately 10–15 feet. Operations were stopped immediately, and no injuries were reported. The driller later stated that torque had not been released prior to the crew placing tongs on the joint. Damage to the tong spring was observed, and further inspection of the equipment will be conducted to determine if additional damage occurred.

incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Transcend Drilling Company Inc
incidents.Incident Description:
Employee was knocking out pins on a load safe.  When the pin cleared, the load shifted resulting in the employees finger getting pinched by a 1" pin.

Investigation to fallow.

incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.Incident Description: While sending HYC elevator from rig floor to catwalk employee was struck in the face.  Employee treated at medical clinic for small cuts to face.  First Aid only.

incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Butch's Trucking Inc
incidents.Incident Description: On December 4, 2025 at approximately 12:42pm, our employee was turning west from JBS onto I-20 when the third-party vehicle in front of him suddenly stopped at the yield sign. The employee was unable to stop in time and made contact with the rear of the third-party vehicle, causing damage to the vehicle’s rear door and bumper. No injuries were reported at the scene.

incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.Incident Description:
Crash Report BCSA 2025-0473922

Mr. Makupson had just dropped off a coworker at home and was exiting the neighborhood at the time of the incident. After turning left onto Talley Rd, a third-party vehicle came over a hill at a high rate of speed and struck Unit 2341 along the driver’s side. The impact pushed Unit 2341 several feet, where it ultimately came to rest against a cement wall.

The other vehicle bounced off Unit 2341, crossed back over to its lane, and continued approximately 124 feet down the bar ditch before coming to a stop. Mr. Makupson reported no injuries at the scene and confirmed the following morning that he was still uninjured. The other driver was transported by ambulance to a local hospital for evaluation. According to law enforcement, the driver was expected to be okay.

Both vehicles were towed from the scene. Unit 2341 was later moved to Butch’s Yard in Pleasanton and will eventually be relocated to the Midland Yard.

At the time of this report, no citations have been issued to Mr. Makupson. Safety is awaiting completion of the official crash report so that third-party information can be collected and added to this report.

incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.Incident Description:
The employee reported that he was traveling southbound on I-27 behind a school bus. The school bus changed lanes unexpectedly, at which point the employee observed that his current lane was closing ahead. The employee stated that he had an opening to safely change lanes and had already passed the other truck involved in the incident.

While the employee was attempting to merge into the adjacent lane, the rear driver-side tire of trailer 1231 made contact with the passenger-side front tire and wheel of the third-party vehicle. The damage appears to be minor and primarily cosmetic.

Post-Incident Actions:

Safety department contacted the third party. They will obtain a repair estimate and follow up once available.

The employee completed post-accident drug and alcohol testing.

The employee will be referred for Smith Systems driver re-education.

Third-Party Information:
Company: Panhandle Express LLC
Address: 133 W. Third St., Hereford, TX 79045
Office: 806-364-2021
Fax: 806-364-2073

Texas DPS responded.  No report filed, No citations issued.
incidents.Rig / Well: South bound 1-27 (Canyon Drive) just south of Amarillo

incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.Incident Description: Employee was driving on Rt 66 in Dennison, OH when the driver stuck a low lying tree branch on the driver side mirror and driver side passenger door while avoiding contact with a deer. There were no injuries and minimal damage to the truck. Employee was sent for a post incident drug and alcohol screen.

incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.Incident Type: At-Fault Vehicle Accident, Equipment Damage/Property Damage
incidents.Incident Description: Employee maneuvered unit to avoid striking wildlife on road, as he corrected the unit it caught the edge of the roadway and flipped on its right side. No injuries to employee or other parties.

incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.Incident Description: On November 18th, 2025 at approximately 11:45am, while rigging up tools on Patterson 263 for Mewbourne Oil Company, Richard Acosta was struck in the right knee by a pair of 13 5/8 power tongs. Crew members Tyler Fitzwillam, Aaron Romero, Acosta, and two Patterson hands were preparing to hoist the power tongs to the rig floor and held a tailgate safety briefing beforehand, where a Patterson hand instructed everyone to stay clear of the off-side where the hoist is located due to the tendency of the tongs to swing that direction once they clear the floor. As the tongs came through the V-door, they began to swing toward drill pipe on the hoist side, and Acosta attempted to steer the tongs away, placing himself in the line of fire and catching his right knee between the tongs and the pipe. Acosta walked down the stairs unassisted and was helped to a truck tailgate, then transported for medical evaluation where x-rays showed no fractures, and he was released to full duty with the case remaining first aid only.

incidents.Report: HSE - Incident Reporting
incidents.Company: Permian Equipment Rentals LLC
incidents.Incident Description:
While backing a mobile vac unit into the yard, the employee cut the wheel to position the trailer and temporarily lost sight of a tilt-deck trailer. As a result, the employee’s Chevrolet pickup (Unit 246) made contact with the tilt-deck trailer, causing damage to the driver’s side door.

Employee will coordinate repairs with Permian Management.

incidents.Report: Initial Quality Report
incidents.Company: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.Descr: Return line that was connected to the power tongs had a hole in it which caused it to leak hydraulic fluid
incidents.ICA/TShoot: Changed out damaged return line from spare unit on location and requested another unit to be hot shot to location.

incidents.Report: Initial Quality Report
incidents.Company: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.Descr: There is a hole on the return line for the hydraulic unit which is leaking hydraulic fluid
incidents.ICA/TShoot: Was able to finish out the job.

incidents.Report: Construction -- Daily Equipment Safety Inspection & Repair Report
incidents.Company: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc

incidents.Report: HSE - Root Cause Analysis Report
incidents.Company: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.Location of Incident:
Exxon Mobil
Rig: Cardinal Coil #4
Well: Weyman-Wood 22P 12-H 
County: Glasscock
incidents.RCA Team Members: Leffy Vance, Kelly Rhodes, Jesus Perez, Jose Romero, Mathew Garcia, Mario Garcia
incidents.Give a brief description of the event: While positioning 4-inch poly line into a clamp to be welded to a hammer union, the employee’s footing slipped, causing the line to shift and strike him in the face. The employee was evaluated at XstremeMD, referred to Midland Memorial Hospital for precautionary imaging, and later returned to XstremeMD and released to full duty with no restrictions.
incidents.What is the employee's level of experien: Employee has over 10 years with Butch’s and is assigned as a Poly Tech. He is experienced and trained for the work being performed.
incidents.What was employee's condition? sick, tir: Employee stated he was not sick, tired, distracted, or complacent at the time of the incident.
incidents.Does the employee understand the expecta: Yes. The employee is familiar with the task and regularly performs this type of poly operation.
incidents.Is the employee qualified for this job?: Yes. The employee has over 10 years of experience with Butch’s and is trained for this work.
incidents.Was the employee rushed in the completio: No. There is no indication the task was being rushed. The crew was nearing completion for the day, but operations were being conducted in a normal manner.
incidents.Additional comments about the Human Fact: The employee was working within his normal role and attempted to steady the poly line when his footing slipped due to slick ground conditions.
incidents.What was the weather like at the time of: Cold evening conditions following the recent snow and ice storm, with clear skies at the time of the incident.
incidents.What were the road conditions like at th: Roadways were not a contributing factor. The work area had muddy and slick ground conditions from recent precipitation and melting ice.
incidents.Was there any other key factors related: Residual moisture from the storm created soft and slippery footing around the work area.
incidents.Additional comments about the weather th: Weather itself was not severe at the time, but post-storm ground conditions increased slip potential in the immediate work area.
incidents.Was there a JSA completed for this job o: Yes. A JSA was completed on January 27, 2026, for the Exxon job covering rig-up production activities and signed by the crew.
incidents.Did the employee receive clear & precise: Yes. The task steps, hazards, and controls were reviewed with the crew prior to starting work.
incidents.Was this incident on location and if so,: Yes. Work was being performed on location with supervision present.
incidents.Were there any un-identified hazards tha: The JSA addressed slips, trips, uneven terrain, pinch points, and hand placement; however, post-storm muddy ground conditions and reduced visibility due to dusk/nighttime lighting conditions should be emphasized further in future pre-task discussions.
incidents.Additional Comments about Communication: Crew members participated in the JSA and acknowledged required PPE and job hazards. Changing site conditions following the storm and fading daylight will be added as specific discussion points during future tailgates for similar poly line operations.
incidents.Was an inspection done on the equipment?: Yes. Pre-use inspections were conducted as part of the job planning process, and no defects were reported with the poly line, clamp, hammer union, or work table.
incidents.Did employee have any concerns over the: No concerns were reported prior to the incident.
incidents.Was there any maintenance issues with th: No known maintenance issues were identified.
incidents.Additional Comments about Equipment fact: The equipment involved was functioning as intended. The incident was not related to equipment failure but rather movement of the poly line after footing was lost.
incidents.Did the employee follow all Policy & Pro: Yes. The employee was performing the task in line with established poly pipe procedures and site requirements
incidents.Did the employee attend a tailgate meeti: Yes. The employee attended the pre-job tailgate meeting and signed the JSA for the task.
incidents.Was Hazard Recognition being performed?: Yes. Hazards such as pinch points, hand placement, slips, and uneven terrain were identified in the JSA; however, changing ground conditions and lighting should be emphasized more during similar operations following weather events.
incidents.Causes:
1. Slick, muddy ground conditions following the recent storm led to loss of footing.

2. Reduced visibility due to dusk/nighttime conditions and limited lighting in the work area.

3. Employee was positioned in the line of fire while manually holding the poly line during positioning.
incidents.Recommended Corrective Actions:
1. Require a second crew member to assist in controlling and securing the poly line in the clamp during positioning and welding.
2. Ensure adequate lighting is in place for evening or low-light operations before work begins.
3. Reinforce line-of-fire awareness and safe body positioning when handling or staging poly line.
4. Conduct a safety standdown for poly crews following weather events to review footing hazards, lighting conditions, line-of-fire exposure, and controls before resuming work.
5. Management to evaluate the use of a long-roller or similar mechanical straightening device to help control poly line during cold weather conditions when the material tends to curl, reducing the need for employees to manually hold the line in place.

incidents.Report: CSG - LEVEL 1 FAILURE REPORT
incidents.Company:: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.1. Failure Summary:: While operating on location, bolts securing the riser on the casing elevators backed out and the threads in the HYC were found to be stripped. The HYC was removed from service and replaced to continue operations.
incidents.2. Immediate Mode of Failure:: Stripped threads in the HYC bolt hole causing the riser bolts on the casing elevators to loosen.
incidents.3. Initial Field Observations:: Bolts holding the riser on the casing elevators were observed backed out during operations. The equipment was secured and the HYC was removed from service. A replacement HYC was hot-shotted to location to minimize downtime.
incidents.4. R&M Inspection Findings:: The removed HYC was returned to the shop where the bolt hole threads were re-threaded. Inspection confirmed thread damage at the bolt seat location.
incidents.5. Contributing Factors: Improper bolt seating and degraded threads in the HYC.
incidents.6. Root Cause: Thread damage in the HYC bolt hole allowed the bolts to back out during operations.
incidents.7. Corrective Actions::
•	Removed the affected HYC from service
	•	Replaced the HYC on location
	•	Re-threaded the damaged bolt hole in the shop
	•	Reviewed proper bolt seating and thread condition checks with shop personnel prior to installation
incidents.9. Next Steps::
•	Reinforce inspection of bolt seating and thread condition prior to running bolts
	•	Monitor similar equipment for comparable thread wear
	•	Continue communication with the shop to prevent recurrence

incidents.Report: CSG - LEVEL 1 FAILURE REPORT
incidents.Company:: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.1. Failure Summary:: While running casing on location, a hydraulic hose on the hydraulic power unit failed. The unit was taken out of service and replaced with another unit to continue operations.
incidents.2. Immediate Mode of Failure:: Hydraulic hose rupture on the hydraulic power unit.
incidents.3. Initial Field Observations:: The hose blew during operations, resulting in loss of hydraulic function. The crew removed the unit from service and a replacement unit was delivered to the location to minimize downtime.
incidents.4. R&M Inspection Findings:: Unit will be inspected with additional focus on hydraulic hoses to check for wear, degradation, or potential defects beyond normal pre-use inspection.
incidents.5. Contributing Factors: Normal wear and tear on hydraulic components.
incidents.6. Root Cause: Hydraulic hose failure due to wear not identified during standard pre-inspection.
incidents.7. Corrective Actions::
- Removed the affected unit from service

- Replaced the unit on location

- Reinforced the need for deeper inspection of hydraulic hoses during pre-use inspections

- Hose inspection criteria will be reviewed with shop and field personnel
incidents.9. Next Steps::
- Review inspection practices with crews to identify hose wear earlier

- Monitor similar units for comparable hose conditions

incidents.Report: CSG - LEVEL 1 FAILURE REPORT
incidents.Company:: Butch's Rat Hole & Anchor Service Inc
incidents.1. Failure Summary:: While running casing, the CRT/CRTe got stuck on the casing and wouldn’t release. The tool was turning but wouldn’t latch up to disengage. The crew spent roughly 1.5–2 hours troubleshooting before the tool finally released. A replacement CRTe was sent to location, and the affected tool was brought back to the shop for teardown.
incidents.2. Immediate Mode of Failure:: Tool would not latch onto the J-hooks and complete the release. Rotation was present, but the tool stayed locked to the casing.
incidents.3. Initial Field Observations::
- Tool stayed engaged on casing even with multiple release attempts.

- Air was bled off; no immediate change.

- One housing bolt was removed to check for trapped air.

- Torque and RPM were increased to 15,000 ft-lbs and 15 RPM.

- After sitting and multiple attempts, the tool finally released.

- When it disengaged, a small amount of trapped air escaped.
incidents.4. R&M Inspection Findings::
* Complete teardown showed no internal damage.

* J-hooks, latch components, mandrel, and internal hardware were all intact.

* No abnormal wear or mechanical failure found.

* Tool was reassembled and passed function tests.
incidents.5. Contributing Factors:
-Trapped air/pressure inside the casing pushing against the tool.

- Unknown whether the 2” valve was opened to relieve pressure.

- Pressure prevented the latch mechanism from lining up with the J-hooks.

- Sitting on the casing allowed the pressure to slowly bleed off.

- Increased torque/RPM helped overcome resistance from pressure.
incidents.6. Root Cause: The issue was caused by trapped pressure inside the casing, which prevented the CRTe from lining up and latching onto the J-hooks during the release. There were no mechanical issues with the tool itself.
incidents.7. Corrective Actions::
* Tool was swapped out on location.

* Full teardown completed; tool cleared and returned to service.

* Reinforced reminder to open the 2” valve to bleed trapped air before attempting tool release.

* Passed along guidance to crews on how trapped pressure can affect disengagement.
incidents.9. Next Steps:: Monitor future runs to see if this becomes a pattern or a one-off pressure situation.
